title: rgts
text: rgts R package makes easier download GridTimeSeries (GTS) data available 1x1 km grid NVE. package use well known R syntax connect data base, downloads data casts easily accessible data.frames. row contains data grid cell given date time. overview use package. brief introduction assumes familiar working spatial data R. make use sf stars packages. Consult packages needed. First load rgts, sf stars packages.
code: library(rgts) library(sf) #> Linking to GEOS 3.10.2, GDAL 3.4.1, PROJ 8.2.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE library(stars) #> Loading required package: abind

title: rgts
text: download GTS data need least one three possible types spatial data input functions. Points coordinates area represented polygon Cellindices first two supposedly require much explanation, either download data one points interest (e.g. position animal) one areas interest (e.g. protected area). third hand less clear. GTS data assignes cellindex 1x1 km grid cell Norway. index starts 0 cell north-western corner numbers cells continuously left right one row time. function gts_create_grid() builds stars raster cellindices attribute. see cellindex starts 0 equal (cellnumber - 1) stars raster. important remember want plot values map.
code: ## Build raster grid <- gts_create_grid() grid #> stars object with 2 dimensions and 1 attribute #> attribute(s), summary of first 1e+05 cells: #>            Min.  1st Qu.  Median    Mean  3rd Qu.  Max. #> cellindex     0 24999.75 49999.5 49999.5 74999.25 99999 #> dimension(s): #>   from   to offset delta                refsys x/y #> x    1 1195 -75000  1000 ETRS89 / UTM zone 33N [x] #> y    1 1550  8e+06 -1000 ETRS89 / UTM zone 33N [y] ## Extract the cellindex of the first five cells grid$cellindex[1:5] #> [1] 0 1 2 3 4

title: rgts
text: obtain cellindices ? point area interest, function gts_cellindex() used extract cellindices grid cells contain point within area. need input function geometry, point(s) polygon(s), sf objects. points can done like like : cellindices can later used query GTS data. Generally, performing queries using cellindices input faster using coordinates polygons. latter two requires API search cellindices looking data.
code: ## Create a data frame with coordinates coords <- data.frame(x = c(58200, 74225), y = c(6708225, 6715025)) coords <- st_as_sf(x = coords, coords = c("x", "y"), crs = 25833) ## Extract cellindices gts_cellindex(geometry = coords) #> [1] 1542878 1534529

title: rgts
text: Sometimes seems valid query may fail need troubleshooting. download functions, prefix gts_dl_..., two optional arguments aid process. First, may set verbose TRUE see exactly sent server. can check provided input data correctly. Second, can set return_raw TRUE function return raw result list query. check output expected type data time span resolution query. handle specific recurring issues using gts_dl_...-functions results error messages server: API accept queries ask data grid cell multiple times. Find cellindices using gts_cellindex perform query unique cellindices using gts_dl_cellindex gts_dl_cellindex_aggr. API upper limit size data can returned query. Limit number cellindices length time series query. Sometimes API returns error message query requests data outside available time spans data missing data database. Check available time spans data using gts_parameters make sure query valid. Next, try shorter time spans figure particular dates missing data. Generally gts_dl_cellindex gts_dl_polygon functions less likely return error messages missing data gts_dl_cellindex_aggr gts_dl_polygon_aggr functions. former two functions better use troubleshooting missing data single dates.

title: rgts
text: encounter clear bug, please file minimal reproducible example github. Questions data needs addressed NVE. General R help can found R Community Stack Overflow. E-mail maintainer urgent private communications.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Thomas Kvalnes. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kvalnes T (2024). rgts: Conveniently download gridded time series data Norway NVE. R package version 0.9.0, https://thomas-kvalnes.github.io/rgts/, https://github.com/thomas-kvalnes/rgts.
code: @Manual{,   title = {rgts: Conveniently download gridded time series data for Norway from NVE},   author = {Thomas Kvalnes},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.9.0, https://thomas-kvalnes.github.io/rgts/},   url = {https://github.com/thomas-kvalnes/rgts}, }

title: Conveniently download gridded time series data for Norway from NVE
text: goal rgts provide convenient methods accessing downloading GridTimeSeries (GTS) data Norway (api.nve./doc/gridtimeseries-data-gts/) Norwegian Water Resources Energy Directorate (NVE). data reposiory contains 1x1 km gridded time series data Norway includes several weather environmental parameters, temperature, precipitation, wind direction strength snow depth. Data available 1h, 3h daily intervals depending variable interest. Many daily variables go back present 1957. Questions data directed NVE, author maintains rgts-package access data.

title: Conveniently download gridded time series data for Norway from NVE
text: can install development version rgts GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("thomas-kvalnes/rgts")

title: Conveniently download gridded time series data for Norway from NVE
text: variables available GridTimeSeries (GTS) data can listed using gts_parameters(). show first five: points interest can download data points grid cells using: Lets create polygon, imagine covers area interest Hardangervidda Norway. can now take polygon download daily temperature data (“tm”) grid cells within polygon. First need convert polygon json using function sf_to_json(). show first 10 lines data. 1x1 km grid cell unique ID, called cellindex. faster query API using cellindices directly instead going way around polygons. cellindices given polygon can obtained daily temperature data can obtained. show first 10 lines data. can also obtain data aggregated across grid cells. need choose method aggregating data, “sum”, “min”, “max”, “avg” “median”. Choosing “avg” can obtain daily averages :

what: List CellIndices in the GridTimeSeries data for a polygon — gts_cellindex
title: List CellIndices in the GridTimeSeries data for a polygon — gts_cellindex
text: Looks CellIndex grid cell GridTimeSeries data intersects polygon set points.

title: List CellIndices in the GridTimeSeries data for a polygon — gts_cellindex
code: gts_cellindex(geometry)

title: List CellIndices in the GridTimeSeries data for a polygon — gts_cellindex
text: geometry sf polygon sf points. coordinate system EPSG:25833.

title: List CellIndices in the GridTimeSeries data for a polygon — gts_cellindex
text: vector CellIndices grid cells GridTimeSeries data intersects geometry.

title: List CellIndices in the GridTimeSeries data for a polygon — gts_cellindex

what: Create the 1x1 km raster in the GridTimeSeries data — gts_create_grid
title: Create the 1x1 km raster in the GridTimeSeries data — gts_create_grid
text: function returns empty stars raster resolution 1x1 km coordinate system EPSG:25833. identical grid used GridTimeSeries data.

title: Create the 1x1 km raster in the GridTimeSeries data — gts_create_grid
code: gts_create_grid()

title: Create the 1x1 km raster in the GridTimeSeries data — gts_create_grid
text: empty stars raster resolution 1x1 km, identical one used GridTimeSeries data. Coordinate system EPSG:25833.

title: Create the 1x1 km raster in the GridTimeSeries data — gts_create_grid
code: ## Create empty raster grid grid <- gts_create_grid() grid #> stars object with 2 dimensions and 1 attribute #> attribute(s), summary of first 1e+05 cells: #>            Min.  1st Qu.  Median    Mean  3rd Qu.  Max. #> cellindex     0 24999.75 49999.5 49999.5 74999.25 99999 #> dimension(s): #>   from   to offset delta                refsys x/y #> x    1 1195 -75000  1000 ETRS89 / UTM zone 33N [x] #> y    1 1550  8e+06 -1000 ETRS89 / UTM zone 33N [y]

what: Download cellwise values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex
title: Download cellwise values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex
text: Downloads data grid cell identified CellIndex (index grid cells GridTimeSeries (GTS) data fra NVE). area, faster gts_dl_polygon(), latter first looks cellindices polygon. Time resolution given choice environmental variable (env_layer) start_date/end_date. E.g. "tm3h" "2023-12-01T06" three hour data temperature collected 06:00 "tm" "2023-12-01" daily average temperature.Note: API cap ~635'000 values download ends error larger queries.

title: Download cellwise values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex
code: gts_dl_cellindex(   cellindex,   env_layer,   start_date,   end_date,   return_raw = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Download cellwise values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex
text: cellindex vector cellindices GTS data downloaded. env_layer quoted abbreviation environmental layer download. E.g. Daily precipitaion = "rr", Temperature =  "tm", Snow depth =  "sd". start_date start date given : 'YYYY-MM-DD'. querying three one hour data, hour given like : format: 'YYYY-MM-DDT06' end_date end date. See start_date. return_raw Set TRUE return raw results query (list) without coercing data.frame. verbose Set TRUE print query console (default FALSE).

title: Download cellwise values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex
text: data frame GTS data associated grid cell step time resolution, e.g. daily values values hour.

title: Download cellwise values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex
code: ## Create a sf polygon and convert to json library(sf) xx <- c(58200, 74225, 58200, 74226) yy <- c(6708225, 6708225, 6715025, 6715025) pol <- st_as_sf(x = data.frame(x = xx, y = yy), coords = c("x", "y"), crs = 25833) pol <- st_as_sf(st_as_sfc(st_bbox(pol))) ## Look up cellindices cells <- gts_cellindex(geometry = pol) ## Download data head(gts_dl_cellindex(cellindex = cells, env_layer = "tm", start_date = "2023-12-01", end_date = "2023-12-01")) #>   cellindex altitude       date  time time_resolution_minutes    unit    tm #> 1   1535708     1245 2023-12-01 00:00                    1440 Celcius -12.9 #> 2   1535709     1314 2023-12-01 00:00                    1440 Celcius -13.5 #> 3   1535710     1177 2023-12-01 00:00                    1440 Celcius -12.5 #> 4   1535711     1083 2023-12-01 00:00                    1440 Celcius -11.9 #> 5   1535712     1096 2023-12-01 00:00                    1440 Celcius -12.1 #> 6   1535713     1100 2023-12-01 00:00                    1440 Celcius -12.1 head(gts_dl_cellindex(cellindex = cells, env_layer = "tm3h", start_date = "2023-12-01T06", end_date = "2023-12-01T09")) #>   cellindex altitude       date  time time_resolution_minutes    unit  tm3h #> 1   1535708     1245 2023-12-01 06:00                     180 Celcius -25.4 #> 2   1535708     1245 2023-12-01 09:00                     180 Celcius -24.5 #> 3   1535709     1314 2023-12-01 06:00                     180 Celcius -24.5 #> 4   1535709     1314 2023-12-01 09:00                     180 Celcius -23.8 #> 5   1535710     1177 2023-12-01 06:00                     180 Celcius -21.9 #> 6   1535710     1177 2023-12-01 09:00                     180 Celcius -21.8

what: Download aggregated values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex_aggr
title: Download aggregated values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex_aggr
text: Downloads returns data aggregated chosen time resolution grid cells identified CellIndex. area, faster gts_dl_polygon_aggr(), latter first looks cellindices polygon. Available methods aggregating sum, min, max, avg median. Time resolution given choice environmental variable (env_layer) start_date/end_date. E.g. "tm3h" "2023-12-01T06" three hour data temperature collected 06:00 "tm" "2023-12-01" daily average temperature.Note: API cap ~635'000 values download ends error larger queries.Warning: function slow 1 3 hour time steps API requires one request per time step requesting daily time steps.

title: Download aggregated values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex_aggr
code: gts_dl_cellindex_aggr(   cellindex,   env_layer,   start_date,   end_date,   method,   return_raw = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Download aggregated values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex_aggr
text: cellindex vector cellindices GTS data downloaded. env_layer quoted abbreviation environmental layer download. E.g. Daily precipitaion = "rr", Temperature =  "tm", Snow depth =  "sd". start_date start date given : 'YYYY-MM-DD'. querying three one hour data, hour given like : format: 'YYYY-MM-DDT06' end_date end date. See start_date. method method aggregating values ("sum", "min", "max", "avg" "median") return_raw Set TRUE return raw results query (list) without coercing data.frame (available daily time steps). verbose Set TRUE print query console (default FALSE).

title: Download aggregated values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex_aggr
text: description

title: Download aggregated values for CellIndex — gts_dl_cellindex_aggr
code: # Example ## Create a sf polygon and convert to json library(sf) xx <- c(58200, 74225, 58200, 74226) yy <- c(6708225, 6708225, 6715025, 6715025) pol <- st_as_sf(x = data.frame(x = xx, y = yy), coords = c("x", "y"), crs = 25833) pol <- st_as_sf(st_as_sfc(st_bbox(pol))) ## Look up cellindices cells <- gts_cellindex(geometry = pol) ## Download data gts_dl_cellindex_aggr(cellindex = cells, env_layer = "tm", start_date = "2023-12-01", end_date = "2023-12-03", method = "avg") #>         date  time time_resolution_minutes    unit    tm_avg #> 1 2023-12-01 00:00                    1440 Celcius -13.07589 #> 2 2023-12-02 00:00                    1440 Celcius -12.50089 #> 3 2023-12-03 00:00                    1440 Celcius -11.95179 gts_dl_cellindex_aggr(cellindex = cells, env_layer = "tm1h", start_date = "2023-12-01T06", end_date = "2023-12-01T12", method = "avg") #>         date  time time_resolution_minutes    unit  tm1h_avg #> 1 2023-12-01 06:00                      60 Celcius -17.05893 #> 2 2023-12-01 07:00                      60 Celcius -20.72232 #> 3 2023-12-01 08:00                      60 Celcius -20.58750 #> 4 2023-12-01 09:00                      60 Celcius -16.98482 #> 5 2023-12-01 10:00                      60 Celcius -19.91161 #> 6 2023-12-01 11:00                      60 Celcius -14.42768 #> 7 2023-12-01 12:00                      60 Celcius -13.41786 gts_dl_cellindex_aggr(cellindex = cells, env_layer = "tm3h", start_date = "2023-12-01T06", end_date = "2023-12-01T12", method = "avg") #>         date  time time_resolution_minutes    unit  tm3h_avg #> 1 2023-12-01 06:00                     180 Celcius -21.57500 #> 2 2023-12-01 09:00                     180 Celcius -21.32500 #> 3 2023-12-01 12:00                     180 Celcius -17.34554

what: Download values at given coordinates — gts_dl_coords
title: Download values at given coordinates — gts_dl_coords
text: Downloads data point (coordinate) grid cell (coordinate system: (EPSG: 25833)) given time resolution. Several coordinates can provided . Time resolution given choice environmental variable (env_layer) start_date/end_date.  E.g. "tm3h" "2023-12-01T06" three hour data temperature collected 06:00 "tm" "2023-12-01" daily average temperature.Note 1: API cap ~635'000 values download ends error larger queries. Note 2: API ends error points cellindex. Use gts_cellindex() check.

title: Download values at given coordinates — gts_dl_coords
code: gts_dl_coords(   coords,   env_layer,   start_date,   end_date,   return_raw = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Download values at given coordinates — gts_dl_coords
text: coords data frame x y coordinates (coordinate system: (EPSG: 25833)) env_layer quoted abbreviation environmental layer download. E.g. Daily precipitaion = "rr", Temperature =  "tm", Snow depth =  "sd". start_date start date given : 'YYYY-MM-DD'. querying three one hour data, hour given like : format: 'YYYY-MM-DDT06' end_date end date. See start_date. return_raw Set TRUE return raw results query (list) without coercing data.frame. verbose Set TRUE print query console (default FALSE).

title: Download values at given coordinates — gts_dl_coords
text: data frame GTS data associated point step time resolution, e.g. daily values values hour.

title: Download values at given coordinates — gts_dl_coords

Daily precipitaion = "rr", Temperature =  "tm", Snow depth =  "sd". start_date start date given : 'YYYY-MM-DD'. querying three one hour data, hour given like : format: 'YYYY-MM-DDT06' end_date end date. See start_date. return_raw Set TRUE return raw results query (list) without coercing data.frame. verbose Set TRUE print query console (default FALSE).

what: Download aggregated values for polygon — gts_dl_polygon_aggr
title: Download aggregated values for polygon — gts_dl_polygon_aggr
text: Downloads returns data aggregated chosen time resolution grid cells within polygon (coordinate system: (EPSG: 25833)). Available methods aggregating sum, min, max, avg median. Time resolution given choice environmental variable (env_layer) start_date/end_date. E.g. "tm3h" "2023-12-01T06" three hour data temperature collected 06:00 "tm" "2023-12-01" daily average temperature. collected 06:00.Note: API cap ~635'000 values download ends error larger queries.Warning: function extremely slow 1 3 hour time steps API requires one request per time step requesting daily time steps.

title: Download aggregated values for polygon — gts_dl_polygon_aggr
code: gts_dl_polygon_aggr(   polygon,   env_layer,   start_date,   end_date,   method,   return_raw = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Download aggregated values for polygon — gts_dl_polygon_aggr
text: polygon polygon json rings spatialReference. Use sf_to_json() convert sf til json. coordinate system EPSG:25833. env_layer quoted abbreviation environmental layer download. E.g. Daily precipitaion = "rr", Temperature =  "tm", Snow depth =  "sd". start_date start date given : 'YYYY-MM-DD'. querying three one hour data, hour given like : format: 'YYYY-MM-DDT06' end_date end date. See start_date. method method aggregating values ("sum", "min", "max", "avg" "median") return_raw Set TRUE return raw results query (list) without coercing data.frame (available daily time steps). verbose Set TRUE print query console (default FALSE).

title: Download aggregated values for polygon — gts_dl_polygon_aggr
text: data frame GTS data aggregated across grid cells polygon step time resolution, e.g. daily values values hour.

title: Download aggregated values for polygon — gts_dl_polygon_aggr
code: ## Create a sf polygon and convert to json library(sf) xx <- c(58200, 74225, 58200, 74226) yy <- c(6708225, 6708225, 6715025, 6715025) pol <- st_as_sf(x = data.frame(x = xx, y = yy), coords = c("x", "y"), crs = 25833) pol <- st_as_sf(st_as_sfc(st_bbox(pol))) pol <- gts_sf2json(pol) ## Download data gts_dl_polygon_aggr(polygon = pol, env_layer = "tm", start_date = "2023-12-01", end_date = "2023-12-04", method = "avg") #>         date  time time_resolution_minutes    unit    tm_avg #> 1 2023-12-01 00:00                    1440 Celcius -13.07589 #> 2 2023-12-02 00:00                    1440 Celcius -12.50089 #> 3 2023-12-03 00:00                    1440 Celcius -11.95179 #> 4 2023-12-04 00:00                    1440 Celcius -12.03571 gts_dl_polygon_aggr(polygon = pol, env_layer = "tm1h", start_date = "2023-12-01T06", end_date = "2023-12-01T12", method = "avg") #>         date  time time_resolution_minutes    unit  tm1h_avg #> 1 2023-12-01 06:00                      60 Celcius -17.05893 #> 2 2023-12-01 07:00                      60 Celcius -20.72232 #> 3 2023-12-01 08:00                      60 Celcius -20.58750 #> 4 2023-12-01 09:00                      60 Celcius -16.98482 #> 5 2023-12-01 10:00                      60 Celcius -19.91161 #> 6 2023-12-01 11:00                      60 Celcius -14.42768 #> 7 2023-12-01 12:00                      60 Celcius -13.41786 gts_dl_polygon_aggr(polygon = pol, env_layer = "tm3h", start_date = "2023-12-01T06", end_date = "2023-12-01T12", method = "avg") #>         date  time time_resolution_minutes    unit  tm3h_avg #> 1 2023-12-01 06:00                     180 Celcius -21.57500 #> 2 2023-12-01 09:00                     180 Celcius -21.32500 #> 3 2023-12-01 12:00                     180 Celcius -17.34554

text: table details parameters available GridTimeSeries data. Use variable names table downloading data.

title: List parameters available in the GridTimeSeries data — gts_parameters
code: ## List first 5 parameters head(gts_parameters(), 5) #>   Name            Fullname NoDataValue RawUnit HumanReadableUnit #> 1   rr          Døgnnedbør       65535      mm                mm #> 2 rr3d Nedbør siste 3 døgn       65535      mm                mm #> 3 rr1h       Nedbør 1 time       65535      mm                mm #> 4 rr3h      Nedbør 3 timer       65535      mm                mm #> 5  rrl                Regn       65535      mm                mm #>   TimeResolutionInMinutes FirstDateInTimeSerie #> 1                    1440           1957-01-01 #> 2                    1440           2010-01-01 #> 3                      60           2010-01-01 #> 4                     180           2010-01-01 #> 5                    1440           1957-01-01

what: rgts: Conveniently download gridded time series data for Norway from NVE — rgts-package
title: rgts: Conveniently download gridded time series data for Norway from NVE — rgts-package
text: set functions accessing downloading GridTimeSeries (GTS) data (api.nve./doc/gridtimeseries-data-gts/) Norwegian Water Resources Energy Directorate (NVE). data reposiory contains 1x1 km gridded time series data Norway includes several weather environmental parameters, temperature, precipitation, wind direction strength snow depth.

title: rgts: Conveniently download gridded time series data for Norway from NVE — rgts-package
text: Maintainer: Thomas Kvalnes thomas.kvalnes@nina.
